confession.devil_appearance: man with hideous black face; hands had talons like a bird of prey, feet were like those of a calf
confession.seduction_context: in bois de Faulx, she was ahead of husband on road when approached by man with hideous black face who sympathised with her hard life and offered her gold and silver. Refused at first, made sign of cross and he disappeared. After another week appeared to her and her husband together around midnight as they were resting 'sur des ripailles' with their loads. She said she would consent to serve him if her husband agreed; he did, so they both entered his service.
sabbat_activities: Persin counseled them to do infinite evil and destroy the goods of the earth, to which she would not consent

testimony.quarrel_subject: Pierrot reproached that his wife was a witch

witnesses.name: Paul Jenin
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: neighbor, lived in house of Mre Jean Solier

testimony.quarrel_subject: Jeannotte had quarrel with wife of late Mre Jean Solier, chirurgien, in whose house he then lived
Jeannotte offered him a drink in a plate, which he refused
earlier the same year he had quarrelled with her and called her witch

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: year of death of previous duke, after calling her witch

witnesses.name: Chrestofle Pierson
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: business relationship, bought cow from Pierrot

testimony.threat_quote: luy cousteroit bon; later told him he would repent; threw a stone at him which missed

testimony.threat_quote: qu'il endurast et qu'il estoit trop meschante

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: after throwing something at fruit tree

testimony.quarrel_subject: she had quarrel with his late wife Catherine about horse which witness had bought from her husband

testimony.quarrel_subject: she asked for some flour as he passed house, which he refused
testimony.threat_quote: he should pass there another time and he would see

timeline.subject: Jeannotte and Pierrot Cosson
timeline.details: taken to Condé (Custines) to be confronted with Idotte Michault, wife of Chrestofle Cordier of Faulx St Etienne. She maintained charges that she had seen them at the sabat

timeline.subject: Jeannotte and Pierrot Cosson
timeline.details: C. M. Rémy asks for evidence to be taken against them

timeline.subject: Jeannotte Cosson
timeline.details: second interrogation, interrupted because of other judicial business

timeline.subject: Jeannotte Cosson
timeline.details: confronted with witnesses; accused some of being thieves

timeline.subject: Jeannotte Cosson
timeline.details: C.M. Rémy asks for question ordinaire et extraordinaire

timeline.subject: Jeannotte Cosson
timeline.details: taken to torture chamber and immediately started to confess

timeline.subject: Jeannotte Cosson
timeline.details: PG asks for death sentence, after confrontation with those she had accused

timeline.subject: Jeannotte Cosson
timeline.details: definitive sentence from Change de Nancy

timeline.subject: Jeannotte Cosson
timeline.details: executed; when she was ready to be taken to execution, she discharged all those she had accused

timeline.subject: Pierrot Cosson
timeline.details: Rémy asks that Pierrot be renvoyé. Change de Nancy approved same day, specifying that he was not liable for costs

timeline.subject: Pierrot Cosson
timeline.details: François Cordier, of Val de Faulx, who had been convicted of witchcraft, was confronted with those he had accused. Maintained charge against Pierrot; at stake said he was not sure he was a witch, but had seen him beating water

timeline.subject: Pierrot Cosson
timeline.details: C.M. Rémy asks for evidence to be taken against Pierrot. Followed by order for this to be done, but no more documents on the case

relationships.evidence_text: Pierrot Cosson and his wife Jeannotte
quarrel with his late wife Catherine
in whose house he then lived

economic_context.details: Chrestofle Pierson bought a cow from Pierrot, half for money down and half on credit - dispute arose when collecting the cow. Jeannotte asked for flour from Claudin Burtin returning from mill, which he refused. She was expelled from la Neuflotte because they could not pay taxes and household members were suspected of stealing. Jean Perrin had taken caution against her for some wood.

harms_catalog.harm_description: horse stopped outside their house and would go no further
became very ill; had great headache and felt as if bellows were being put to his ears. This lasted 6 weeks
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: wife of late Mre Jean Solier had quarrel with Jeannotte; Paul asked her why she did this, since latter was reputed a witch
harms_catalog.method_alleged: threw 'un petit juillon' on his hat

harms_catalog.harm_description: developed a swelling on forehead which lasted a month. Was not painful, but only cured when a vagabond woman from Metz advised his father of a method - had forehead bound up as tightly as he could bear for 9 days, and said 9 paternosters and 9 ave marias each day
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Jeannotte offered him a drink in a plate, which he refused

harms_catalog.harm_description: thrown to ground from horse and had a foot dislocated
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: earlier the same year he had quarrelled with her and called her witch
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: year of death of previous duke, after calling her witch
harms_catalog.method_alleged: little black dog ran under legs of his horse

harms_catalog.harm_description: became very ill; genitals were swollen and limbs paralysed. 10 week illness, started to recover after getting bread, salt, and ashes from her house
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: bought a cow from Pierot, she did not want to let him collect it in absence of husband, told him the cow 'luy cousteroit bon'; later she passed him and told him he would repent; threw a stone at him which missed
harms_catalog.method_alleged: witchcraft, cured by bread, salt, and ashes from her house

harms_catalog.harm_description: unknown illness; Jeannotte handled him, then advised pilgrimage to St Chrestofle. Sent him 5 apples to eat, saying the last must be eaten one half raw and the other cooked. After this was done he recovered
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: brother had previously thrown something at one of her fruit trees, and she told him off
harms_catalog.method_alleged: gave illness then cured with apples

harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: his horses were near her garden, and she told him to take them away; he replied that they were doing no harm. She said he would repent if he did not do so

harms_catalog.harm_description: fell ill and died after languishing for 4 years, saying that Jeannotte had bewitched her
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: quarrel about horse which witness had bought from her husband
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: 6 years earlier, died after languishing for 4 years

harms_catalog.harm_description: fell and injured his side as he was carrying 2 sacks of flour past her door
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: was taking flour home from mill, and she asked for some as he passed house, which he refused. She said he should pass there another time and he would see

harms_catalog.method_alleged: at solicitation of devil master Persin

extraction_metadata.notes: Very detailed trial record with 19 witness testimonies. Jeannotte confessed under threat of torture, then retracted accusations against accomplices at execution. Pierrot was released (renvoyé) but later re-accused by François Cordier. No further documents exist after November 12, 1618 order to take evidence against Pierrot. Multiple themes: economic disputes (cow, flour, taxes), healing/cursing duality, expelled from previous village. Devil named Percin, described as cold as marble with talons and calf feet. Confession includes classic elements: seduction, sabbat, sexual relations with devil, making weather. Notable that she refused devil's counsel to do infinite evil. Jeannotte's age approximately 70, mentioned being 15 during Brandenburg War (guerre de Brandebourg).
